metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C# Get Started
C# IDE
The easiest way to get started with C# is to use an IDE.
content.html: The easiest way to get started with C# is to use an IDE.

content.text: An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is used to edit and compile code.
content.html: An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is used to edit and compile code.

content.text: In our tutorial, we will use Visual Studio Community, which is free to download from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/community/ .
content.html: In our tutorial, we will use Visual Studio Community, which is free to download from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/community/.

content.text: Applications written in C# use the .NET Framework, so it makes sense to use Visual Studio, as the program, the framework, and the language, are all created by Microsoft.
content.html: Applications written in C# use the .NET Framework, so it makes sense to use Visual Studio, as the program, the framework, and the language, are all created by Microsoft.

content.text: C# Install
Once the Visual Studio Installer is downloaded and installed, choose the .NET workload and click on the Modify/Install button:
content.html: Once the Visual Studio Installer is downloaded and installed, choose the .NET workload and click on the Modify/Install button:

content.text: After the installation is complete, click on the Launch button to get started with Visual Studio.
content.html: After the installation is complete, click on the Launch button to get started with Visual Studio.

content.text: On the start window, choose Create a new project :
content.html: On the start window, choose Create a new project:

content.text: Then click on the "Install more tools and features" link:
content.html: Then click on the "Install more tools and features" link:

content.text: Choose "Console App (.NET Core)" from the list and click on the Next button:
content.html: Choose "Console App (.NET Core)" from the list and click on the Next button:

content.text: Enter a name for your project, and click on the Create button:
content.html: Enter a name for your project, and click on the Create button:

content.text: Visual Studio will automatically generate some code for your project:
content.html: Visual Studio will automatically generate some code for your project:

content.text: The code should look something like this:
content.html: The code should look something like this:

content.code_html:
using System;

namespace HelloWorld
{
  class Program
  {
    static void Main(string[] args)
    {
      Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");    
    }
  }
}

content.text: Don't worry if you don't understand the code above - we will discuss it in detail in later chapters. For now, focus on how to run the code.
content.html: Don't worry if you don't understand the code above - we will discuss it in detail in later chapters. For now, focus on how to run the code.

content.text: Run the program by pressing the F5 button on your keyboard (or click on " Debug " -> " Start Debugging "). This will compile and execute your code. The result will look something to this:
content.html: Run the program by pressing the F5 button on your keyboard (or click on "Debug" -> "Start Debugging"). This will compile and execute your code. The result will look something to this:

content.code_html:
Hello World!
C:\Users\Username\source\repos\HelloWorld\HelloWorld\bin\Debug\netcoreapp3.0\HelloWorld.exe (process 13784) exited with code 0.
To automatically close the console when debugging stops, enable Tools->Options->Debugging->Automatically close the console when debugging stops.
Press any key to close this window . . .

content.text: Congratulations ! You have now written and executed your first C# program.
content.html: Congratulations! You have now written and executed your first C# program.

content.text: Learning C# At W3Schools
When learning C# at W3Schools.com, you can use our "Try it Yourself" tool, which shows both the code and the result. This will make it easier for you to understand every part as we move forward:
content.html: When learning C# at W3Schools.com, you can use our "Try it Yourself" tool, which shows both the code and the result. This will make it easier for you to understand every part as we move forward:

content.code_html:
using System;

namespace HelloWorld
{
  class Program
  {
    static void Main(string[] args)
    {
      Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");    
    }
  }
}
